titleproper.value: Guide to the Fred Hoyt family collection <num>ARC.043</num>

creation.value: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace <date>2018-11-14T15:56:47</date>

extent.value: in one manuscript box, one drop front box, and five photograph frames.

abstract.value: This collection contains papers and photographs, circa 1850 to 1974, collected during genealogical research by Fred Hoyt. Materials in the collection relate to Hoyt's ancestors, including his parents, Alma Jacobson Hoyt and Lewis S. Hoyt, his maternal grandparents, Ernestine Aschner Jacobson and Isaac W. Jacobson, maternal great-grandparents, Abraham and Jeannette Wachsmann Aschner, as well as aunts and great-uncles.

p.value: Identification of item, date (if known); Fred Hoyt family research collection, ARC.043, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.

Abraham and Jeanette Wachsmann (b. 1827) Aschner were German natives who immigrated to New York around 1870. The Aschners lived at 135 Liberty Street in Manhattan and later moved to 67 Pineapple Street in Brooklyn Heights. Abraham Aschner opened a cigar shop in the 1880s, and at the peak of his success owned six cigar emporiums in Manhattan and Brooklyn. The Aschners had six children: Herman, Isidor, Amos, Frederick B., Nathan, and Ernestine.  Ernestine Aschner married prominent Brooklyn attorney Isaac W. Jacobson in 1894, and the couple had four daughters: Madeline Jacobson-Cox, also an attorney; Juliette Jacobson-Aschner, a teacher; Jeanette Jacobson Gould; a teacher; and Alma Jacobson Hoyt. Around 1909, the Jacobson family relocated to Montgomery, in Orange County, N.Y., where Alma Jacobson married Lewis S. Hoyt in 1933. Their son was Fred Hoyt.

Photographs in the collection include framed portraits, cabinet cards, cartes-de-visite, tintypes, and both black-and-white and color prints of the Wachsmann, Aschner, Jacobson, and Hoyt families. The bulk of images in the collection are cabinet cards from the late 19th century, with fewer items dating from the mid-20th century. Cartes-de-visite originate from Germany and depict German relatives of the Wachsmanns and Aschners, while all cabinet cards were taken in Manhattan and Brooklyn and show immediate and extended members of the Aschner and Jacobson families. A large number of portraits show of Alma Jacobson, her sisters, and her parents. The collection also contains interior shots of Abraham Aschner's cigar store on Fulton Street, both interior and exterior views of Aschner and Jacobson family homes in Brooklyn, and Alma Jacobson's 1922 drivers license issued in New York City.
